stem: Based on the findings, which action should the nurse take FIRST?

options.text: Prepare for immediate endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy.
Administer a nebulized racemic epinephrine treatment.
Obtain a stat portable chest X-ray to rule out pneumonia.
Initiate intravenous access and administer a bolus of normal saline.

sections.title: Situation
sections.content: A 3-year-old male, J.B., presented to the ED at 14:00 with acute respiratory distress. The mother reports that J.B. woke up this morning with a sore throat and fever. His condition has rapidly deteriorated over the past few hours. He is now drooling and having difficulty swallowing. He is sitting upright, leaning forward, with his chin thrust out.

sections.title: Background
sections.content: J.B. has no significant past medical history or known allergies. He is up-to-date on his vaccinations. He has had no recent illnesses or injuries. Mother denies any foreign body ingestion. He was previously healthy and active.

sections.title: Assessment
sections.content: On arrival, J.B. is anxious and restless. He has a high-pitched inspiratory stridor and a muffled voice. He is using accessory muscles to breathe. His oral examination reveals significant swelling of the epiglottis. Oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. He is increasingly agitated and unable to lie down. Retractions are noted at the suprasternal notch. Current respiratory rate is 40 and labored. Heart rate is 150 bpm. Temperature is 104째F (40째C) rectally. 14:15: The patient appears increasingly fatigued and cyanotic around the lips.

sections.title: Recommendation
sections.content: I recommend immediate airway management. J.B. requires either endotracheal intubation or a tracheostomy to secure his airway. Pediatric ENT and Anesthesia have been notified and are en route. Consider IV antibiotics after the airway is stabilized. Continuous monitoring of vital signs and respiratory status is crucial.

data.Respiratory: Stridor, retractions, use of accessory muscles, cyanosis around lips
data.ENT: Drooling, muffled voice, difficulty swallowing, swollen epiglottis

data.Goal: Maintain patent airway and adequate oxygenation
data.Interventions: Continuous monitoring of respiratory status, prepare for intubation/tracheostomy, administer oxygen, administer medications as ordered

rationale.correct: Epiglottitis is a rapidly progressive infection that can cause complete airway obstruction, particularly in young children. The patient's presentation (drooling, stridor, tripod positioning, and low oxygen saturation) indicates severe respiratory distress and imminent airway compromise. The priority is to secure the airway through endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy. Delaying this intervention could result in respiratory arrest and death. Pediatric ENT and Anesthesia are en route but the nurse must prepare for the procedure.
rationale.incorrect:
Nebulized racemic epinephrine can help reduce upper airway edema, but in severe cases of epiglottitis, it may not be sufficient to prevent complete airway obstruction. Securing the airway is the priority.
A chest X-ray may be useful in diagnosing other respiratory conditions, but in a patient with suspected epiglottitis, the priority is to secure the airway. Delaying airway management to obtain a chest X-ray could have fatal consequences.
While IV access is important for administering fluids and medications, it is not the immediate priority in this situation. Securing the airway takes precedence over establishing IV access. The patient's immediate survival depends on maintaining a patent airway.

answerBreakdown.analysis: Correct. The patient's symptoms indicate severe respiratory distress and imminent airway obstruction. Preparing for immediate intubation or tracheostomy is the priority.
Incorrect. Racemic epinephrine can reduce airway edema, but securing the airway is the priority in severe cases of epiglottitis.
Incorrect. A chest X-ray is not the priority in this situation. Securing the airway takes precedence.
Incorrect. Establishing IV access is important but secondary to securing the airway.

clinicalPearls: Epiglottitis is a medical emergency that requires immediate airway management.
The classic presentation of epiglottitis includes the '4 Ds': Dysphagia, Drooling, Distress, and Dysphonia.
Avoid agitating the child, as crying can worsen airway obstruction.
Always have airway equipment readily available when assessing a child with suspected epiglottitis.

questionTrap.trap: Selecting interventions that address symptoms without addressing the underlying airway obstruction.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation). In this case, airway patency is the absolute priority. Recognize that the patient's condition is rapidly deteriorating and requires immediate intervention to secure the airway.

mnemonic.title: AIRWAY
mnemonic.expansion: Assess Airway Immediately, Intubate if necessary, Respiratory support, Watch for deterioration, Always be prepared, Yes, act quickly!
